citation.article-title: Taxonomic study of bacteria isolated from Lebanese spring waters: proposal for Pseudomonas cedrella sp. nov. and P. orientalis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas orientalis sp. nov.
Pseudomonas orientalis (ori. en' tao lis M. L. masc. Adj. orientalis pertaining to the Orient)
The type strain is CFML 96-170T, and has been deposited in the Collection of the Institut Pasteur as CIP 105540T.
The description is based on data of the following strains: CFML 96-170T (= CIP 105540T), CFML 96-164, CFML 96-167, CFML 96-178, CFML 96-166, and CFML 96-174.
The G+C content of the DNA is 60 mol%.
Cell and colonial characteristics.
Cells are Gram-negative, asporogenous, and rod-shaped.
They appear to be motile and a single polar flagellum was observed (figure 2).
When grown on nutrient agar, colonies are smooth, circular, and nonpigmented.
Biochemical and physiological characteristics The fluorescent pigment is produced on both King B and S1 medium [18].
Strains are positive in catalase, oxidase, and urease.
They are able to grow at low temperature (4°C) and also at low salt concentration (0.8%).
Levan is produced from sucrose.
In anaerobic conditions, cells are able to hydrolyze arginine by arginine dihydrolase.
Cetrimide is assimilated.
No growth is reported at high salt concentrations (5 and 7%).
No phenazine pigment production occurs on King A medium.
All strains reduced nitrate to nitrite but were not able to denitrify.
Strains fail to decarboxylase lysine and ornithine.
Indole and acetoin reactions are negative.
No growth occurs at 41°C.
The 2,3,5-triphenyltetrazolium chloride test (TTC) is negative.
Cells do not possess the following enzymatic activities: coagulase, elastase, DNase, or phenylalanine desaminase.

Assimilation of carbon compounds All strains utilize the following substrates as carbon and energy sources (Biotype-l00 system, BioMerieux): α-D(+) glucose, β-D(+) fructose, D(+) galactose, D(+) trehalose, D(+) mannose, D(-) ribose, L(+) arabinose, D(+) xylose, D(+) arabitol, L(-) arabitol, xylitol, myo-inositol, D-mannitol, D-sorbitol, adonitol, D-saccharate, mucate, L(-) malate, trans-aconitate, D-glucuronate, D-galacturonate, 2-keto-D-gluconate, protocatechuate, 4-hydroxybenzoate, (-) quinate, trigonelline, betain, caprate, caprylate, succinate, fumarate, glutarate, DL-glycerate, ethanolamine, D-glucosamine, 3-hydroxybutyrate, D-alanine, L-serine, malonate, L-tyrosine, α-ketoglutarate.

Strains are unable to assimilate the following substrates: α-D(+) melibiose, D(+) raffinose, maltotriose, maltose, α-lactose, lactulose, 1-0methyl-β- galactopyranoside, 1-O-methyl-agalactopyranoside, D(+) cellobiose, β-gentiobiose, 1-O-methyl-β-D-glucopyranoside,palatinose, α-L(-) fucose, D(+) melezitose, dulcitol, D-tagatose, maltitol, D(+) turanose, D-lyxose, i-erythritol, 1-O-methyl-α-D-glucopyranoside, 3-O-methyl-D-glucopyranose, L(+) tartrate, D(+) tartrate, meso-tartrate, tricarballylate, 5-keto-D-gluconate, phenylacetate, gentisate, 3-hydroxybenzoate, benzoate, 3-phenylpropionate, m-coumarate, histamine, 5-aminovalerate, tryptamine.
Enzymatic tests (APIZYM system, BioMerieux)
All strains possess the following enzymatic activities: esterase-lipase (C8), trypsine, phosphatase acid.
No strain possesses the following enzymatic activities: lipase (C14), valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, β-glucosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase.
Strains of P. cedrella and P. orientalis were isolated from Lebanese spring waters.
No clinical significance is known.
